item.title: This week in the DBA Universe - 2015-11-25
item.author: nathan@dba-team.com (Nathan Jolly)
item.description:
I expect things will quiet down on the database news front as North American companies take some time off for Thanksgiving and head towards the Christmas holidays.

SQL Server

  • SQL Server 2012 SP3 is available! Kendra Little (BrentOzar.com) points out some great additions to DMVs which have been backported from SQL Server 2016
  • Brent Ozar had a neat list of things that are worth checking if your SQL Server suddenly becomes slow
  • The SQL Server DBCC SHOW_STATISTICS command is going to be even useful with this step-by-step guide on how to interpret the results

MySQL

  • Dimitri Kravtchuk (Oracle) has an interesting comparison of the 1M+ QPS metrics posted for both MySQL 5.7 and MariaDB 10.1. Possibly worth a read just for the comments discussion between Dimitri and Mark Callaghan
  • MyDumper 0.9.1 is available - this is quite a major release and includes a number of features that may make it a viable alternative to mysqldump for logical backups
  • If you’re looking to poke around MySQL 5.7 but don’t have the inclination to spin up your own VM / container, you can look into db4free.net, which now offers MySQL 5.7 databases free for testing
  • Vadim Tkachenko (Percona) offers more third-party analysis of Amazon’s Aurora service. There are a few interesting risks which I hadn’t considered
  • Shlomi Noach (booking.com) has a great, if slightly biased (he maintains an alternative product) run-down of limitations in MariaDB’s MaxScale product

General

  • ITNews reports on a December 1 cease-sale of Oracle SE and SE1 (in favour of SE2) which may have serious licensing implications for some users. If you use Oracle you might want to take a look
  • Robert Harris (StorageMojo) offers some analysis on Dell’s recent acquisition of EMC. This industry seems to be endlessly cyclical but even for on-premise compute the trend seems to be towards deploying on commodity baremetal rather than VMs on expensive storage, so I’m not sure how much mileage there is in EMC’s product suite
  • What affects remote workers the most? A small survey by Moishe Lettvin (Etsy) suggests it’s not discipline, but communication and loneliness that can be the biggest challenges. George Stocker (Jewelbots), another remote worker, offers some suggestions for trying to work around the biggest challenges of remote work

item.title: This week in the DBA Universe - 2015-11-10
item.author: nathan@dba-team.com (Nathan Jolly)
item.description:
There’s a lot of activity in the MySQL world over the past couple of weeks in the wake of MySQL 5.7’s GA release.

SQL Server

  • Kendra Little (BrentOzar.com) points out that the StackExchange dataset makes an excellent tool for testing (or developing) TSQL writing skills
  • Microsoft have released SQL Server 2016 CTP3. Lots of strong improvements including analytics, the cloud, encryption, JSON, temporal tables and in-memory, though one would imagine that Standard edition servers aren’t going to see most of this

MySQL

  • Vitor Oliveira (Oracle) offers some benchmarks on MySQL 5.7’s Multi-threaded slave feature, and the numbers are looking very promising
  • Peter Laursen (Webyog) points out that using MySQL 5.7’s computed columns could cause problems for non-native backup/restore tools
  • SeveralNines are continuing their excellent «Become a MySQL DBA» blog series with tips on analysing the MySQL Error Log and Galera diagnostic logs
  • There’s been a bit of coverage of Aurora:
    • Marco Tusa (Pythian) indicates that a Galera setup can generally outperform a similarly specced Aurora instance
    • Yves Trudeau (Percona) offers a «first look» at RDS Aurora, including pros/cons and some speculation about how it might work
  • Percona offers up a bunch of new releases, including Toolkit 2.2.16, Percona Server 5.6.27, and Percona Server 5.5.46
  • Mark Leith offers slides from a talk about the MySQL sys schema, which is now bundled into MySQL 5.7 and available separately for other version

General

  • Chris Ueland of MaxCDN offers a nice summary of Netflix’s technology stack
  • HighScalability points out the Hasso-Plattner-Institut’s Genealogy of Relational Database Management Systems. This is really cool
  • Researchers Daniel Abadi and Jose Faleiro propose a theorum about tradeoffs with distributed NoSQL systems that they call the FIT theorum: Fairness, Isolation or Throughput (pick any two)

item.title: about
item.author: nathan@dba-team.com (Nathan Jolly)
item.description:
About Nathan

I’m a full-time database administrator, and have had the privilege of working with a broad number of database technologies during my career. I currently spend most of my time working with MySQL and Microsoft SQL Server.

I hold professional-level certifications in DB2, Microsoft SQL Server and MySQL.

I generally take a «horses for courses» approach where database technology is concerned - I’m far more interested in getting the job done than to wax philosophical about why one particular technology is best.

item.title: An Introduction
item.author: nathan@dba-team.com (Nathan Jolly)
item.description:
The first posts you’ll see on this site are titled «This week in the DBA universe».

Which is incorrect on a number of levels, not least:

  • They are collated somewhere between weekly and monthly
  • They focus on SQL Server and MySQL news, which are a very, very small subset of the DBA universe

However, it’s the best title I’ve got for now.

Pythian’s log buffer has a great set of curated content focused on database development and design, but I hope this is helpful for people who’d like to keep up to date with what’s new with database software and toolsets themselves.
